• 'However extensive the doctrine of mutual mistake may be, it applies only in Cases where, either from the terms of the contract or otherwise, the essence of the contract is the truth of the common assumption': (Viscount Hailsham).
• 'The thing which in such a case is common to both parties to the contract and is in their mutual contemplation is not a fact which is or is not a term of the contract but a fact which does or does not affect the very substratum of the contract': (Viscount Dunedin).
• 'The contract is not voidable because the parties were under a mistake of fact in assuming that a certain state of affairs existed; it is voidable because that mistake relates to the essential basis on which the contract was made': (Lord Atkin).

cases.name: Stannard v Gore [2012] EWHC 1655
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Stannard v Gore [2012] EWHC 1655, the claimant, Mr Stannard, was the owner of a tyre fitting business.
• He stored a large number of tyres on his property, which subsequently caught fire due to an electrical fault.
• The fire spread to the neighboring property owned by Mr Gore, causing significant damage.
• Mr Gore initiated legal proceedings against Mr Stannard, claiming that the storage of the tyres constituted a 'nuisance' in tort law.

Issues
• The primary issue for determination was whether the storage of the tyres constituted a nuisance.
• Mr Gore argued that the storage of the tyres, which led to the fire, amounted to an unreasonable interference with the use of his property.
• Mr Stannard, on the other hand, contended that the storage of tyres was part of his lawful business activity and was not unreasonable in the circumstances.
• For a nuisance claim to succeed, Mr Gore needed to prove that the defendant's use of the land had caused substantial and unreasonable interference.

Decision
• The High Court judge, Mr Justice Coulson, found in favor of Mr Stannard, holding that the storage of tyres did not constitute a nuisance.
• The court reasoned that, while the fire had caused substantial interference, the necessary requirement of it being unreasonable had not been met.
• This was based on previous case law, such as Leakey v National Trust for Places of Historic Interest [1980] QB 485, that held the defendant's use of land must be unreasonable as opposed to the consequences of that use.
• As a result, Mr Gore's claim was dismissed.

Key passage(s)
• 'There was no evidence that the mere storage of the tyres amounted to a nuisance before the fire started.' (Coulson J)
• 'I have come to the conclusion that Mr Stannard's use of his land, that is, the storage of the tyres, was not unreasonable.' (Coulson J)
• 'Accordingly, Mr Gore's claim for damages for nuisance fails.' (Coulson J)

cases.name: Entick v Carrington [1765] EWHC KB J98
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 1762, the King's messengers, John Entick and Nathan Carrington, were granted a warrant by Lord Halifax, the Secretary of State, to search Entick's home for seditious materials.
• The messengers broke into Entick's house, causing damage, and seized his papers.
• Entick sued Carrington and the other messengers for trespassing and damaging his property.

Issues
• Entick argued that the warrant granted by Lord Halifax was invalid because it was a general warrant and therefore did not specify any legal basis for the search.
• Carrington claimed that the authority of the Secretary of State granted them the right to search and seize material under a general warrant.

Decision
• The court held that the warrant was invalid, as it was a general warrant without any legal basis for the search and seizure of Entick's papers.
• Carrington was held liable for the trespass and damage caused during the search.
• The court emphasized the importance of the sanctity of an individual's home and the protection of property rights.

Key passage(s)
• 'Every invasion of private property, be it ever so minute, is a trespass. No man can set his foot upon my ground without my license, but he is liable to an action, though the damage be nothing.' (Lord Camden)
• 'If this point should be determined in favour of the jurisdiction, the secret cabinets and bureaus of every subject in this kingdom will be thrown open to the search and inspection of a messenger, whenever the Secretary of State shall think fit to charge, or even to suspect, a person to be the author, printer, or publisher of a seditious libel.' (Lord Camden)

cases.name: Airedale NHS Trust v Bland [1993] AC 789
cases.summary:
Facts
• Tony Bland, a victim of the Hillsborough disaster, suffered severe injuries and was in a persistent vegetative state (PVS) for over three years.
• The hospital sought a declaration from the court that discontinuing life-sustaining treatment (withdrawing artificial nutrition and hydration) would be lawful.
• The patient's family supported this decision.

Issues
• Airedale NHS Trust argued that continuing treatment would not be in Bland's best interests and sought to withdraw it.
• The Official Solicitor, representing Bland's interests, opposed the withdrawal of treatment, arguing no legal basis existed for ending life-sustaining treatment on the basis of 'best interests'.

Decision
• The House of Lords unanimously held that withdrawing treatment was lawful in this case.
• They distinguished between acts of commission (actively ending life) and omission (withdrawing life-sustaining treatment).
• The Lords found that withdrawing treatment was in Bland's best interests, as there was no realistic prospect of his condition improving.
• This case was an important step in the development of the 'best interests' test.

Key passage(s)
• Lord Goff: 'I would emphasise that in cases where the question can be legitimately asked whether the treatment proposed is intended to sustain life, or whether it is intended to save a life, it is not desirable to condone some boundary, which may involve imprecise terminology with the result that the lawfulness of that treatment depends on where the boundary is struck.'
• Lord Browne-Wilkinson: 'Once it had been established that a PVS patient had no truly patient conscious or cognitive function, the patient's death occurred when the family, the doctors and the court, pursuant to its well-established jurisdiction, came to the conclusion that the feeding should cease.'
• Lord Keith: 'I share the view of my noble and learned friends that the withdrawal from Anthony Bland of the artificial feeding measures would not be unlawful, either as amounting to a criminal act or as exposing any of those involved in it to any form of civil liability.'

cases.name: Ghaidan v Godin-Mendoza [2004] UKHL 30
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant (Mr. Ghaidan) was the landlord of a flat that had been occupied by the respondent (Mr. Godin-Mendoza) and his same-sex partner, who later passed away.
• Mr. Ghaidan sought to recover possession of the flat under the Rent Act 1977, but Mr. Godin-Mendoza claimed that as the surviving member of the couple, he was entitled to become the statutory tenant.
• The Rent Act required that for a person to inherit tenancy rights, they must have been living with the deceased tenant 'as his or her wife or husband'.

Issues
• Whether Mr. Godin-Mendoza could be considered as living 'as husband' with the deceased tenant despite them being in a same-sex relationship, which did not fit the traditional interpretation of 'husband'.
• Mr. Ghaidan argued that the wording of the Act required a heterosexual relationship, and therefore the tenancy could not pass to Mr. Godin-Mendoza.
• Mr. Godin-Mendoza argued that the Act could be interpreted in a way to include same-sex partners in a stable and committed relationship.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the relationship between Mr. Godin-Mendoza and the deceased tenant met the requirements of the Act, allowing Mr. Godin-Mendoza to inherit the tenancy.
• The Lords relied on the Human Rights Act 1998 (HRA) in their decision, finding that a wider interpretation of the Rent Act was necessary to prevent discrimination on the grounds of sexual orientation.
• The case overruled Fitzpatrick v Sterling Housing Association [1999], which had previously held that same-sex partners could not meet the criteria of the Act.

Key passage(s)
• 'The cases demonstrate that the task of the court is to apply Convention rights to the facts of the individual case before it... most importantly... where to read the legislation so as to give effect to the rights of the parties would go 'against the grain' of the legislation, altering or extending the policy of the statute' (Lord Nicholls).
• 'If words of a statute are plain, the court must take the statute as it finds it... The court must do this, even if this means that the statute is incompatible...the court has no power to redress or modify the incompatibility itself by rewriting the statute' (Lord Hoffmann).
• 'Once it is accepted that sexual orientation cannot legitimately be the cause of different treatment, the concept of 'spouse' cannot be treated as confined to persons of the opposite sex' (Lord Slynn).

cases.name: Henderson v Merrett Syndicates Ltd [1995] 2 AC 145
cases.summary:
Facts
• Henderson v Merrett Syndicates Ltd [1995] 2 AC 145 is a landmark English tort law case that established the principle that damages may be awarded for negligent misrepresentation.
• In this case, the plaintiffs were Names (investors) at Lloyd's of London, and the defendants were the managing and members' agents.
• The plaintiffs had suffered financial loss due to the defendants' alleged negligent management of the underwriting accounts and poor selection of risks to insure.
• They had received written assurances from the defendants promising strict monitoring and effective management of their investments.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the defendants, as managing and members' agents, owed the plaintiffs a duty of care in tort for negligent misrepresentation in addition to their contractual obligations.
• The plaintiffs argued that the defendants were liable for negligence, while the defendants argued that their liability was limited to their contractual obligations and they did not owe a separate duty of care in tort.

Decision
• The House of Lords unanimously held that the defendants owed the plaintiffs a duty of care in tort for negligent misrepresentation, in addition to their contractual obligations.
• The court found that a duty of care may coexist with a contractual obligation and that, in this case, the defendants had assumed responsibility for the investment management, which created a special relationship and the tortious duty of care.
• Consequently, the defendants were held liable for the plaintiffs' economic loss arising from their negligence.
• The court also relied on the landmark case Hedley Byrne & Co Ltd v Heller & Partners Ltd [1964] AC 465, which established the principle that a duty of care may arise in the context of economic loss due to negligent misrepresentation.

Key passage(s)
• '[T]here is no reason in principle why a person who is under a contractual duty to take care in the performance of the contract should not be subject to a like duty of care under the law of tort. The duty arises not because the representation forms part of the contract but because the representor has assumed a special relationship, and hence responsibility, with the representee.' (Lord Goff)
• 'The parellelism between the contractual and the tortious duty will in many cases make it unnecessary to plead both claims, but the coexistence of the claims leaves the plaintiff free to select so much of the course that offers the best advantage.' (Lord Mustill)

cases.name: Mortgage Corporation v Shaire [2001] EWCA Civ 1758
cases.summary:
Facts
• The claimant, Mortgage Corporation, granted a mortgage to a Mr. B and Miss S.
• The defendants, Mr. and Mrs. Shaire, entered into a guarantee with the claimant to secure the mortgage.
• The guarantee limited the defendants' liability to £80,000 plus interests and costs.
• Mr. B and Miss S defaulted on the mortgage repayments, and the claimant sought to enforce the guarantee.
• The defendants argued that the guarantee was unenforceable due to undue influence or misrepresentation.

Issues
• The claimant argued that the guarantee was valid and enforceable.
• The defendants argued that the guarantee was unenforceable due to (i) undue influence by Mr. B, (ii) non-disclosure by the claimant of material facts, and (iii) misrepresentation by the claimant's solicitors.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that the guarantee was unenforceable due to undue influence by Mr. B and non-disclosure by the claimant.
• The court applied the decision in Royal Bank of Scotland v Etridge (No 2) [2001] UKHL 44, which requires lenders to take reasonable steps to ensure that guarantors are not acting under undue influence or misrepresentation.
• The court found that the claimant's solicitors did not meet the necessary standard in Etridge to protect the defendants from undue influence or with adequate information to make an informed decision.
• The court did not consider whether there was misrepresentation by the claimant's solicitors.

Key passage(s)
• 'In the circumstances of this case...we agree with [counsel for the defendant] that, even if the solicitors had taken all reasonable steps to satisfy themselves that Mrs. Shaire was not subject to undue influence, they failed to take reasonable steps to ensure that she was in possession of all material facts.' (Lord Justice Chadwick)
• 'What was plainly lacking in the present case was any attempt by the solicitors to explain to Mrs. Shaire the true extent of the risk which she was running.' (Lord Justice Chadwick)

cases.name: R (ProLife Alliance) v BBC [2004] UKHL 23
cases.summary:
Facts
• The ProLife Alliance (Appellants) challenged the BBC's (Respondents) refusal to broadcast a party election broadcast (PEB) that contained graphic images of aborted foetuses.
• The respondents deemed the broadcast inappropriate for pre-watershed transmission.
• Both the High Court and Court of Appeals had ruled in favour of the respondents.

Issues
• The appellants argued that the refusal to broadcast the PEB engaged Article 10 (right to freedom of expression) of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR).
• The respondents claimed that the decision was justified under Article 10(2) of the same convention on the grounds of protecting morals and the rights of others.

Decision
• The House of Lords unanimously dismissed the appeal.
• Their Lordships upheld that the decision of the respondents was proportionate and protected the rights of others under Article 10(2) of the ECHR.

Key passage(s)
• Lord Nicholls of Birkenhead: '[To] strike a fair balance between the importance of the right to freedom of expression... and the need to protect the public from unsuitable material... the courts should respect the guidelines adopted by broadcasters unless there are compelling grounds for doing otherwise.'
• Lord Hoffmann: '[The ProLife Alliance] are seeking to cloak a political tactic in the garb of human rights. Their claim should be rejected.'
• Lord Scott of Foscote: '[A] pre-watershed ban on offensive material transmitted on television or radio would not prevent political parties having access to the media to put forward their political views.'

cases.name: Attorney General v Guardian Newspapers (No 2) [1990] 1 AC 109
cases.summary:
Facts
• The action was brought by the Attorney General causing the Guardian Newspapers and several other papers to halt publication of an article titled 'The Spy-Catcher Affair'.
• The article concerned the contents of Peter Wright's memoirs, an ex-MI5 officer who wrote a book titled 'Spycatcher', banned from publication in the UK.
• The book included allegations of unlawful conduct by UK security services.

Issues
• The Attorney General sought an injunction against the newspapers to prevent them from publishing the article about the book.
• The newspapers argued that they were exercising their freedom of speech and the government was seeking to suppress legitimate and lawful information.
• Interlocutory injunctions blocking the publication were granted. However, the courts had to reconsider the matter, as key aspects of the book were published in other countries.

Decision
• The House of Lords upheld the permanent injunctions prohibiting the publication of the articles detailing the contents of 'Spycatcher'.
• The court held that the newspapers were under an obligation of confidence not to publish information in the book, and as such, there was no public interest in its publication.

Key passage(s)
• 'In the field of press confidentiality, the vital public interest which justifies an interference with press freedom is the need to protect private individuals against serious injury to their personal lives and reputations.' (Lord Keith)
• 'Once it is accepted, as it must be, that unlawful allegations derived from the book 'Spycatcher' are publications which are forbidden in our law, there can be no ground for allowing newspapers to give any further publicity to that which must remain unpublished.' (Lord Bridge)

cases.name: Central London Property Trust Ltd v High Trees House Ltd [1947] KB 130
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 1937, Central London Property Trust Ltd (CLP) leased a block of flats to High Trees House Ltd (HTH) at a rent of £2,500 per year for 99 years.
• Due to the outbreak of World War II and subsequent lack of demand for flats, CLP agreed in 1940 to reduce the rent to £1,250 per year.
• By 1945, the demand for flats had increased, and CLP sought to restore the original rent.

Issues
• CLP claimed HTH should pay the original rent for the second half of 1945 and onwards, arguing that the 1940 agreement was only a temporary concession due to low demand during the war.
• HTH contended that CLP had waived its right to claim the original rent under the doctrine of promissory estoppel.

Decision
• The court held that the original rent should be restored from the second half of 1945, as the circumstances of the war, which had given rise to the rent reduction, had ceased.
• The doctrine of promissory estoppel was applied, preventing CLP from claiming the arrears for the period in question when the reduced rent was paid.
• Although estoppel could not provide a cause of action, it could be used as a defense to prevent CLP from enforcing the original rent during the low-demand period.

Key passage(s)
• 'A promise intended to be binding, intended to be acted on and in fact acted on, is binding so far as its terms properly apply.' - (Denning J)

cases.name: R v Gibbons and Proctor [1918] 13 Cr App R 134
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R v Gibbons and Proctor, the two defendants, William Gibbons and Helen Proctor, were living together but unmarried.
• Gibbons had a daughter from a previous relationship, who was in the care and custody of the two defendants.
• Due to persistent ill-treatment and neglect by the defendants, the child eventually died of starvation.
• The two were charged with the murder of the child.

Issues
• The main issue in this case was whether the defendants' responsibility towards the starving child could be considered a legal duty, breaching which would warrant criminal charges.
• The defendants argued that they did not have a legal duty towards the child, and their behavior could not be considered criminal.
• The prosecution argued that the defendants had a legal duty to care for the child and by not providing the necessary nourishment, they violated their duty.

Decision
• The Court of Criminal Appeal affirmed the convictions of murder against both Gibbons and Proctor.
• The court held that the defendants had a legal duty towards the child and by failing to provide necessary care and nourishment, they were guilty of the offence of murder.
• The decision drew on the case of R v Instan [1893] 1 QB 450, where it was held that a person can be held criminally liable for neglecting their legal duty towards another person.

Key passage(s)
• 'Where two persons are charged with a crime which can only be committed by the two acting together, and there is evidence upon which a jury might find that one is acting under the domination of the other, or is of such weak intellect or will as to be unable to resist the other, it may be advisable, in order to prevent a miscarriage of justice, to separate the two trials. But there is no such rule of law.' - Lord Reading CJ

cases.name: R (Hicks) v Commissioner of Police for the Metropolis [2017] UKSC 9
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 2012, the claimant, Hicks, was detained by police officers during the Queen's Diamond Jubilee celebrations in London.
• She was arrested to prevent a breach of the peace and was released shortly after the end of the event.
• Hicks sought judicial review of her detention, arguing that her arrest and detention were unlawful and violated her rights under the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR).

Issues
• Hicks argued that her arrest and detention were unlawful and violated her rights under ECHR.
• The Commissioner of Police for the Metropolis, on the other hand, argued that the detention was necessary to prevent a breach of the peace and was therefore lawful.

Decision
• The UK Supreme Court held that Hicks' arrest and detention were lawful.
• The Court found that the police officers had acted lawfully in arresting and detaining Hicks to prevent a breach of the peace, a common law power which they were entitled to use.
• The Court also held that her detention did not violate her rights under the ECHR.
• In reaching the decision, the Court applied the test set out in the case of Austin v Commissioner of Police for the Metropolis (Austin) [2009] UKHL 5, which established that a detention would be proportional if it was necessary to prevent harm to others and the individual's rights were outweighed by the risk of harm.
• The Court found that Hicks' detention was necessary to prevent a breach of the peace and did not violate her ECHR rights, as her rights were outweighed by the risk of harm to others.

Key passage(s)
• 'The judges in Austin were divided as to what would constitute an arbitrary deprivation of liberty contrary to Article 5, but they were unanimous in their view that it would be wrong as a matter of both common law and ECHR jurisprudence to hold that a lawful and non-arbitrary detention could violate Article 5.' (Lord Neuberger)

cases.name: R v Wilson [1996] 2 Cr App R 241
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R v Wilson [1996] 2 Cr App R 241, the defendant, Mr. Wilson, was charged with Actual Bodily Harm (ABH) under section 47 of the Offences Against the Person Act 1861.
• The charge arose from an incident where Mr. Wilson had branded his initials onto his wife's buttocks with a hot knife at her request.
• The act caused her to suffer third-degree burns, but she had consented to the branding.
• Mr. Wilson was convicted in the Crown Court, and he appealed the conviction to the Court of Appeal.

Issues
• The issue in this case was whether or not branding one's wife with a hot knife, at her request, amounts to an offence under section 47 of the Offences Against the Person Act 1861 (ABH).
• The prosecution argued that the wife's consent did not negate the defendant's criminal liability, whereas the defense argued that she had given her informed consent and thus there was no criminal act.
• Both parties referred to the leading case on consent, R v Brown [1993] 2 All ER 75, where it was held that consent was not a defense to a charge of ABH unless it was for a recognized public benefit (e.g. medical treatment).

Decision
• The Court of Appeal quashed Mr. Wilson's conviction.
• Lord Justice Russell held that the defendant's actions did not fall within the category of cases where consent was not a defense, as outlined in R v Brown.
• It was noted that the branding was conducted in the context of the couple's marriage and not for the purposes of inflicting pain or injury.
• The court distinguished this case from R v Brown, as the branding was not seen as harmful to society or 'seriously reprehensible'.

Key passage(s)
• '[A]bsent any and valid countervailing factors, an accused acting in good faith is not criminally responsible for inflicting such harm on his wife if he does so with her consent.' (Lord Justice Russell)

cases.name: Barton v Armstrong [1976] AC 104
cases.summary:
Facts
• Barton, a shareholder in a company, pressured Armstrong, the director, to buy his shares at an inflated price.
• Barton threatened to kill Armstrong if he refused and even hired a hitman.
• Armstrong eventually agreed to buy Barton's shares, but later sought to have the contract set aside, claiming it was induced by duress.

Issues
• Armstrong: Contract should be set aside due to illegitimate pressure and duress, rendering the contract voidable.
• Barton: Duress does not apply as Armstrong was under no immediate physical threat when signing the contract.
• The court had to determine whether the contract could be set aside due to duress when no immediate physical threat was present during contract formation.

Decision
• The Privy Councilheld that the contract could be set aside due to duress.
• It was irrelevant whether Barton's threats had a significant influence on Armstrong's decision to enter the contract.
• A contract entered into under duress, even without immediate physical threat, rendered the contract voidable.
• The case extended the principle of duress to include threats of violence from past incidents influencing a party's decision to enter a contract.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is enough if the threats were a cause, although not the sole cause, unless it is shown that the threats did not contribute at all to the decision.' (Lord Cross)
• 'So it cannot be an objection to setting aside a contract on the ground of duress that the party subjected to duress acted not only under it but out of fear of other evil consequences... [There] was a causal connection between the threats and the decision.' (Lord Wilberforce)

cases.name: R (Al-Saadoon) v Secretary of State for Defence [2010] UKSC 2
cases.summary:
Facts
• The case of R (Al-Saadoon) v Secretary of State for Defence [2010] UKSC 2 involved the detention and alleged torture of two Iraqi civilians by British forces in Iraq.
• The claimants, Faisal Attiyah Nassar Al-Saadoon and Khalef Hussain Mufdhi, were detained by British forces in 2003 and were suspected of murdering two British soldiers.
• They were transferred to Iraqi authorities despite concerns that they would face a risk of torture, inhuman treatment, or the death penalty.

Issues
• The claimants brought a claim for judicial review
• They argued that their detention and transfer to Iraqi authorities were in breach of the UK's obligations under the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR).
• The UK government argued that the ECHR did not apply to British forces operating in Iraq and that the transfer was lawful.

Decision
• The Supreme Court held that the ECHR applied to the claimants because they were within the jurisdiction of the UK while detained by British forces.
• The Court found that the transfer to Iraqi authorities was in breach of the ECHR because it exposed them to a real risk of torture or inhuman treatment.
• However, the Court held that the claimants were not entitled to damages because the UK had no obligation to disobey Iraqi law and retain the claimants in detention.

Key passage(s)
• 'In a case such as the present, there is no reason to treat the Iraqi courts differently from those of a contracting state to the Convention.' (Lord Rodger)
• 'The real risk of torture, or inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment and the risk of imposition and execution of the death penalty each constituted breaches of articles 3 and 2 of the Convention..' (Lord Phillips)

cases.name: McDonald's Corporation v Steel & Morris [1997] EWHC 366 (QB)
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 1990, McDonald's filed a libel suit against Helen Steel and David Morris, environmental campaigners from the London Greenpeace group.
• Their 'Factsheet', circulated in the late 1980s, accused McDonald's of numerous unethical business practices, including exploiting workers and being responsible for rainforest destruction and animal cruelty.
• Although it was dismissed as a test case under the Legal Aid Act, McDonald's sought damages under private law.

Issues
• The key issue was whether the factsheet distributed by Steel and Morris contained sufficient 'defamatory statements' about McDonald's to warrant a violation of its rights.
• McDonald's argued that the accusations made in the factsheet were baseless and defamatory, while Steel and Morris maintained that they were true and represented valid, held opinions.
• Both parties were unrepresented, leading to one of the longest civil trials in English legal history - lasting over 300 days.

Decision
• The High Court, led by Justice Bell, found that some of the accusations made in the factsheet were defamatory, but others, such as the company's poor treatment of its workers and exploitative advertising practices, were substantially true.
• Damages were initially set at £60,000 but were later reduced to £40,000 on appeal.
• A subsequent appeal against the ruling by Steel and Morris to the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) was successful on grounds that the trial process was unfair as they were denied legal aid and faced a massive corporation in court, a violation of their right to a fair trial under Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is adjudged that the said leaflet is to a substantial extent true... that the Plaintiffs have been guilty of wrongful advertising...and that they pay the Defendants' taxed costs of this action and of the assessment thereof.' (Justice Bell)

cases.name: Société Générale v Geys [2012] UKSC 63
cases.summary:
Facts
• Société Générale, a French multinational bank, terminated the employment of its senior executive, Mr. Raphael Geys.
• The unilateral termination of his employment took place on 29 November 2007, while at the time Gecko_Chakeris was on sick leave.
• The bank made a payment-in-lieu of notice (PILON) but did not inform Mr. Geys about it until 18 December 2007.
• Mr. Geys claimed that he was still entitled to a significant bonus as his employment had not been effectively terminated at the time the bonus was calculated.

Issues
• The main issue in this case was whether the act of making the PILON, without informing Mr. Geys, was sufficient to terminate his employment contract.
• Société Générale argued that the bank's remittance of the PILON to a separate bank account constituted effective termination, despite not informing Mr. Geys.
• Mr. Geys argued that his employment had not been effectively terminated until he was notified of the PILON, and therefore, he was still entitled to the bonus.

Decision
• The UK Supreme Court held, in a majority judgment, that the bank's failure to inform Mr. Geys about the PILON meant that his employment had not been effectively terminated.
• As a result, Mr. Geys was entitled to the bonus in question.

Key passage(s)
• 'Clear and unequivocal words, or conduct, to bring the employment to an end are needed' (Lord Dyson).
• 'The parties are not free to attach any meaning they choose to the words in their contracts ... One should be mindful of the fact that there is often ... a close relationship between the rules of construction and the implication of terms.' (Lord Hope).
• 'Only after notification of the summary termination by the employer to the employee can the contract of employment be treated as at an end.' (Lady Hale).

cases.name: Ridge v Baldwin [1964] AC 40
cases.summary:
Facts
• Ridge, a Chief Constable, was dismissed from his position by the Watch Committee (Baldwin) after being acquitted of conspiracy to obstruct justice in a criminal trial.
• Ridge sought a declaration that his dismissal was void and an injunction preventing his dismissal.

Issues
• Ridge argued that his dismissal was unlawful based on principles of natural justice, namely the requirement of a fair hearing before an impartial tribunal, and that he was not given the opportunity to hear and respond to the case against him.
• Baldwin argued that the principles of natural justice did not apply to the Watch Committee's decision to dismiss Ridge.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the dismissal was indeed void, as the Watch Committee had failed to afford Ridge the principles of natural justice (fair hearing and impartiality).
• This decision established the application of natural justice principles to the dismissal of public officials like Ridge.

Key passage(s)
• 'The crucial question in every case is: what does the subject-matter and the context of it in the particular conditions of the statutory power, require by way of natural justice?' (Lord Reid)
• 'Before a man can be condemned or dismissed or suffer forfeiture, he must have the opportunity of defending himself or necessarily of correcting or contradicting any relevant statement prejudicial to his view.' (Lord Hodson)
• 'I would accept the statement of Jervis, C.J., ... that the principle is that no man is to be condemned unheard; that it extends to civil cases as well as criminal cases; and that it applies to any decision to be made by any person having the power of making it by Statute, Order in Council, or any bye-law of any institution.' (Viscount Dilhorne)

cases.name: Associated Provincial Picture Houses Ltd v Wednesbury Corporation [1948] 1 KB 223
cases.summary:
Facts
• Associated Provincial Picture Houses Ltd (the appellant) operated a cinema in Wednesbury.
• Wednesbury Corporation (the respondent) granted a license for the operation of the cinema, but with a condition prohibiting children under 15 years of age from attending the cinema on Sundays.
• The appellant applied to have this condition removed.
• The application was refused by the respondent.
• The appellant sought judicial review of the respondent's decision.

Issues
• The appellant argued that the condition was unreasonable and that the respondent had not exercised its discretion properly in imposing it.
• The respondent contended that the condition was necessary to protect the morals of the town's children.
• The issue before the court was whether the respondent's decision was so unreasonable that no reasonable authority, having properly considered the matter, could have arrived at it (the Wednesbury unreasonableness test).

Decision
• The Court of Appeal dismissed the appellant's application for judicial review.
• The Court held that the respondent's decision did not meet the threshold for Wednesbury unreasonableness.
• In making its decision, the respondent had not taken into account any irrelevant considerations or failed to take into account any relevant ones.
• The Court also concluded that the condition was not so unreasonable that no reasonable authority could have imposed it.

Key passage(s)
• 'If, in the statute conferring the discretion, there is to be found expressly or by implication matters which the authority exercising the discretion ought to have regard to, then in exercising the discretion it must have regard to those matters.' (Lord Greene MR)
• 'A person entrusted with a discretion must direct himself properly in law.' (Lord Greene MR)
• 'The test is whether the decision...is so unreasonable that no reasonable authority could ever have come to it.' (Lord Greene MR)

cases.name: Salomon v A Salomon & Co Ltd [1897] AC 22
cases.summary:
Facts
• Salomon, a leather merchant, incorporated his business, selling it to A. Salomon & Co Ltd, a newly created company.
• In return, Salomon received 20,001 shares, the remaining six shares valued at £1 each distributed to his family members. He also received £10,000 worth of debentures (secured debts) for the business he sold.
• The company became insolvent, and a liquidator was appointed.
• The liquidator claimed that the company was a sham and Salomon was its alter ego, therefore he should be liable for the company's debts.

Issues
• Salomon argued that the company and he were separate legal entities, and that the company should be responsible for its corporate debts, following incorporation.
• The liquidator argued that the company was a sham and should not be allowed to take advantage of limited liability protection.

Decision
• The House of Lords, rejecting the liquidator's argument, held that Salomon was not personally liable for the company's debts.
• They ruled that A Salomon & Co Ltd was a separate legal entity, distinct from its shareholders, by looking at the Companies Act 1862 (now replaced by the Companies Act 2006).
• Even though Salomon and the company were virtually the same, for legal purposes, they needed to be treated as distinct parties once the company had been validly incorporated.
• As a result, Salomon could benefit from limited liability protection, which the Act afforded to all shareholders.

Key passage(s)
• 'Either the limited company was a legal entity, or it was not... the company is at law a different person altogether from the subscribers to the memorandum [of association]; and, though it may be that after incorporation the business is precisely the same... the company is not in law the agent of the subscribers or trustee for them' (Lord Macnaghten)
• 'It has become the fashion to call companies of this class “one-man companies.” Everyone knows what is meant by it... But the doctrine of the Court of Chancery is that if a company complies with the terms of its incorporation and registration, it is a separate person from its shareholder' (Lord Herschell)

cases.name: Gillick v West Norfolk and Wisbech Area Health Authority [1986] AC 112
cases.summary:
Facts
• Mrs. Gillick, a mother of five daughters, sought a declaration from the court that prescribing contraceptive treatment for minors without parental consent was unlawful.
• She challenged the guidance issued by the Department of Health and Social Security (DHSS), which allowed doctors to provide contraceptive advice and treatment to minors without parental consent in certain circumstances.
• The guidance was based on the 'Fraser guidelines,' developed by Lord Fraser in response to the case Re S (A Minor) [1986].

Issues
• Mrs. Gillick argued that the DHSS guidance infringed upon parental rights and responsibilities to safeguard the welfare of their children.
• She also contended that the guidance violated the criminal law regarding the encouragement of underage sexual activity.
• The health authority, defending the guidance, argued that it was necessary for doctors to exercise discretion in providing advice and treatment to protect the welfare of the patients and that it was not against the criminal law.

Decision
• House of Lords, by a majority (3:2), decided in favor of Mrs. Gillick stating that the DHSS guidance was unlawful.
• The majority held that parental rights could only be overridden in exceptional circumstances where the child's welfare was at risk and consent must be sought from the person with parental responsibility.
• They did not find the guidance to be in conflict with the criminal law.
• Lord Scarman and Lord Bridge dissented, arguing that the guidance was lawful as it was in line with the common law principle of necessity and the best interest of the child.

Key passage(s)
• 'Parental right yields to the child's right to make his own decisions when he reaches a sufficient understanding and intelligence to be capable of making up his own mind...' (Lord Scarman)
• 'In my opinion, the law should be that the parental right, whether the case concerns contraception, or any other treatment ... exists in the interests of the child, and it exists only so long as it is needed.' (Lord Fraser)
• '...the parental right to determine whether or not their minor child below the age of 16 will have medical treatment terminates if and when the child achieves sufficient intelligence and understanding to enable him or her to comprehend the issues involved...' (Lord Scarman)

cases.name: Council of Civil Service Unions v Minister for the Civil Service [1985] AC 374
cases.summary:
Facts
• The applicant, the Council of Civil Service Unions (CCSU), challenged the Prime Minister's decision to ban trade unions at the Government Communications Headquarters (GCHQ), a department of the civil service responsible for intelligence.
• The ban was made pursuant to the royal prerogative, an executive power historically held by the monarch, by order of the Minister for the Civil Service.
• The Divisional Court dismissed the applicant's claim, but the Court of Appeal reversed the decision in favor of the applicant, holding that the decision was subject to judicial review.

Issues
• The respondent argued that the Prime Minister's decision, made under the royal prerogative, was not subject to judicial review as it concerned national security and matters of high policy.
• The applicant argued that the Prime Minister's decision was open to judicial review because it affected the contractual rights of the civil servants concerned and infringed their rights under the European Convention on Human Rights.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that decisions made under the royal prerogative are subject to judicial review, but the subject matter of this particular decision was non-justiciable as it involved national security - a matter for the executive, not the courts.
• The appeal was allowed.

Key passage(s)
• 'The fact that the source of the power is the prerogative and not statute cannot of itself be a sufficient reason for excluding judicial review.' (Lord Scarman)
• 'The judges are neither the parents nor the guardians of political conventions; they are merely the trustees. For better or worse, the offspring is now launched on the world.' (Lord Diplock)

cases.name: R v Hutchinson [1990] RTR 209
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R v Hutchinson [1990] RTR 209, the defendant, Hutchinson, was observed driving erratically.
• He was stopped by the police who suspected he was under the influence of alcohol.
• A breath test was not possible due to Hutchinson being deaf and dumb.
• The police requested a blood test, but Hutchinson refused indicating that he was a Jehovah's Witness.
• The blood test would have involved the transfer of blood, which was against his religious beliefs.

Issues
• The key issue in the case was whether Hutchinson's refusal to provide a blood sample for a test due to his religious beliefs amounted to a reasonable excuse under the Road Traffic Act 1988 (RTA).
• The prosecution argued that his refusal was not a reasonable excuse.
• The defence argued that his religious beliefs provided a reasonable excuse for his refusal.

Decision
• The court held that a person's religious beliefs may provide a reasonable excuse for refusing a blood test under the RTA.
• In this case, Hutchinson's refusal was considered a reasonable excuse due to his sincere religious beliefs.
• However, the court added that whether a refusal constitutes a reasonable excuse depends on the individual circumstances of each case.

Key passage(s)
• 'The question whether a particular reason amounts to the grievous and invidious term 'reasonable excuse' is very much a matter of degree and depends upon opinions, instincts and connexions.' (Watkins LJ)
• 'We think it would be wrong to categorise as unreasonable the refusal of a person to provide a blood sample for a test under section 7 of the 1988 Act, if that person genuinely and sincerely believes that to provide such a sample would imperil his soul.' (Watkins LJ)

cases.name: Bolitho v City and Hackney Health Authority [1998] AC 232
cases.summary:
Facts
• The plaintiff, Patrick Bolitho, a two-year-old child, suffered severe brain damage and died after experiencing respiratory failure.
• He was admitted to St. Bartholomew's Hospital, managed by the City and Hackney Health Authority (defendant), with croup symptoms.
• A nurse decided to not intubate the child due to his failure to follow the consultant's instructions.
• If intubation had taken place, the child would not have suffered brain damage.

Issues
• The plaintiff argued that the defendant was negligent in failing to intubate the child.
• The defendant argued that the decision not to intubate was a reasonable professional judgment, applying the principle set out in Bolam v Friern Hospital Management Committee [1957] 1 WLR 582 (Bolam test).

Decision
• The House of Lords allowed the defendant's appeal, noting that expert medical evidence cannot always determine negligence.
• The court held that the Bolam test involved not only considering whether a doctor's actions fell within a range of reasonable professional practice, but also whether the expert practice itself was reasonable.
• In this case, the court found that the doctor's decision not to intubate was reasonable, and the defendant was not liable for negligence.

Key passage(s)
• 'But if, in a rare case, it can be demonstrated that the professional opinion is not capable of withstanding logical analysis, the judge is entitled to hold that the body of opinion is not reasonable or responsible.' (Lord Browne-Wilkinson)
• '[T]he court is not bound to hold that a defendant doctor escapes liability for negligent treatment or diagnosis just because he leads evidence from a number of medical experts (rocking-elbow or pile-taking fraternity) who are genuinely of opinion that the defendant’s treatment or diagnosis accorded with sound medical practice.' (Lord Scarman)

cases.name: R v White [1910] 2 KB 124
cases.summary:
Facts
• The defendant, George White, administered poison to his mother with the intention of killing her.
• His mother died of unrelated heart issues before the poison could take effect.
• White was charged with attempted murder and found guilty by a jury at trial.
• He appealed the conviction to the Court of Appeal.

Issues
• The defendant argued that his actions did not constitute attempted murder because he had not actually caused his mother's death.
• The prosecution argued that White's intentions were sufficient to constitute attempted murder, even if he ultimately did not cause the death.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal allowed the appeal and quashed White's conviction.
• The court held that since the poison had not actually caused the mother's death, the defendant's actions did not amount to attempted murder.
• The court found that White could not be held liable for murder or attempted murder, but could be liable for administering poison in contravention of the Offences Against the Person Act 1861 (OAPA).

Key passage(s)
• 'The question...is, did the administration of the poison to the deceased amount at law to an attempt to murder her, inasmuch as she received the poison and it passed into and was absorbed by her system? It is evident that until the poison so operated on her system that it became irremediable, it could not be conclusive that the woman was dead either in law or in fact' (Lord Alverstone CJ).
• 'In my judgment, the act done by this man, who administered the poison to the old woman with intent to cause her death, if an attempt to commit murder, must have been so independently of what subsequently happened... But here, the woman died of heart disease, and not of poisoning, and it seems to me difficult to say that there was evidence that the poison was absorbed into her system so as to produce any effect at all' (Lord Alverstone CJ).

cases.name: Shogun Finance Ltd v Hudson [2002] UKHL 62
cases.summary:
Facts
• Shogun Finance Ltd (SFL) entered into a hire purchase agreement for a car with a fraudster who pretended to be someone else.
• The fraudster then sold the car to an innocent third party, Malcolm Hudson.
• SFL sought to recover the car from Hudson, arguing that the contract of sale between the fraudster and Hudson was void because of the fraud.

Issues
• The primary issue was whether the contract was void or voidable due to the fraud and whether SFL could recover the car.
• SFL argued that the contract was void ab initio (from the beginning) as they had never intended to contract with the fraudster.
• Hudson argued that the contract was only voidable, meaning that title had passed to him through the sale.

Decision
• In a 3-2 majority, the House of Lords held that the contract between SFL and the fraudster was void ab initio and that Hudson had no valid claim to the car.
• This is consistent with the previous decision in King's Norton Metal Co Ltd v Edridge, Merrett & Co Ltd (1897), where a contract was held to be void because of a mistaken identity caused by fraud.
• The minority, however, argued that the contract should be seen as voidable, so as to protect the innocent third party.

Key passage(s)
• 'The owner's right to recover his property is not prejudiced by the fact that an innocent third party is involved. It is not a defence in conversion.' - Lord Hobhouse (majority)
• 'Whilst there was no effective transfer of property to [the fraudster], there was an effective transfer of possession; and he had possession with the owner's authority.' - Lord Nicholls (dissent)
• 'This appeal is, I think, a classic illustration of the mischief which results when doctrine obscures policy in the development of the law.' - Lord Millett (dissent)

cases.name: Natives of the Island of Chagos Archipelago v Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs [2008] UKHL 56
cases.summary:
Facts
• The British government established the British Indian Ocean Territory (BIOT) in 1965, which included the Chagos Archipelago.
• Between 1967 and 1973, the UK forcibly removed the native inhabitants of the Chagos Archipelago to make way for a US military base on Diego Garcia.
• In 2000, the UK High Court held in R (Bancoult) v. Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs (No 1) [2001] QB 1067 that the removal of the Chagossians was unlawful.
• However, in 2004 the UK enacted Orders in Council that effectively reversed this decision, banning the Chagossians from returning.
• The Chagossians challenged the validity of these Orders.

Issues
• The Chagossians argued that the Orders were ultra vires (beyond the legal power) of the Crown.
• They claimed that the Orders violated their fundamental rights and concerns for the environment were not properly addressed.
• The UK government argued that the Orders were valid, and that Crown prerogative powers can be exercised to legislate for BIOT.

Decision
• The case reached the House of Lords, which is now replaced by the Supreme Court.
• By a 3-2 majority, the Law Lords upheld the Orders, finding them to be legal and within the scope of the Crown prerogative powers.
• Lord Hoffmann and Lord Rodger gave dissenting judgments.

Key passage(s)
• 'In this case, although I am conscious of the great wrong which has been done to the Chagos Islanders, I cannot say that, as a matter of law, the British Indian Ocean Territory (Constitution) Order 2004 or the British Indian Ocean Territory (Immigration) Order 2004 was irrational.' (Lord Hoffmann)
• 'What matters is that there is a real risk that, if the Orders are quashed, new legislation will have to be enacted which exposes the United States' defence interests or those of this country to such a risk...The court is not equipped to decide what is reasonably necessary for the defense of the realm or the part which the facilities at Diego Garcia play in its defense.' (Lord Rodger)

cases.name: Woolmington v DPP [1935] UKHL 1
cases.summary:
Facts
• Woolmington, the appellant, was 17-years-old when he shot his wife and killed her.
• He claimed the shooting was accidental, as he was only attempting to threaten suicide in order to encourage his wife to come back to him after she had left.
• The jury found him guilty of murder and he was sentenced to death.
• The Court of Criminal Appeal upheld the conviction, and Woolmington appealed to the House of Lords.

Issues
• Woolmington argued that the judge at his trial had misdirected the jury and that the burden of proof should be on the prosecution to prove his intent to kill, not on him to disprove it.
• The Crown (DPP) argued that, since Woolmington's action constituted an unlawful act (actus reus), he had to prove that he had no intent to kill (mens rea) and thereby disprove the assumed malice aforethought.
• This case considered the nature and scope of the presumption of innocence and the burden of proof in criminal cases.

Decision
• The House of Lords (UKHL) unanimously allowed Woolmington's appeal, holding that the burden of proof is always on the prosecution to prove guilt and that this principle is 'golden thread' of English criminal law.
• It found that the trial judge had misdirected the jury when he said that Woolmington needed to disprove malice on his part, since it was up to the Crown to prove it.

Key passage(s)
• 'Throughout the web of the English Criminal Law one golden thread is always to be seen that it is the duty of the prosecution to prove the prisoner's guilt.' (Viscount Sankey LC)
• 'No matter what the charge or where the trial, the principle that the prosecution must prove the guilt of the prisoner is part of the common law of England and no attempt to whittle it down can be entertained.' (Viscount Sankey LC)

cases.name: Rigby v Chief Constable of Northamptonshire [1985] 1 WLR 1242
cases.summary:
Facts
• The plaintiff, Rigby, owned a shop.
• His shop window was broken during a demonstration by the National Front, following which a crowd hostile to the National Front gathered outside.
• The police officer, Chief Constable of Northamptonshire, instructed two officers to forcibly remove the offensive material from Rigby’s shop window.
• The two police officers damaged the shop window during the removal process.

Issues
• Rigby claimed damages from the Chief Constable for the damage caused to his shop window.
• The Chief Constable argued that they were acting under the doctrine of necessity (intra vires), and therefore were not liable for the damages.
• Rigby argued the police had acted in excess of their powers, amounting to trespass (ultra vires).

Decision
• The court dismissed Rigby’s claim for damages on the basis that the police were acting in order to prevent a breach of the peace and damage to property.
• The court held that the officers were acting within the range of their power, relying on the case of Southam v Smout [1964] 1 QB 308.
• The court ruled that the police had acted under the doctrine of necessity.

Key passage(s)
• 'The police were justly proud of their independent role under the Queen's peace; they did not act as the servants of those with whom they had contact in the public street. The defendant could not escape liability by arguing that he was acting in the plaintiff's interests' (Lord Denning MR).
• 'The trial judge directed himself in terms of the doctrine of necessity - need for the due performance of [policeman's] duty imposed upon him coupled with the virtue of the necessity of the circumstances - and requiring him to do what he did' (Dillon LJ).
• 'It follows, therefore, that I consider that the trial judge rightly decided that the policemen were not trespassers and so liable in damages for what they did' (Dillon LJ).

cases.name: Adams v Naylor [1946] KB at 219
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Adams v Naylor [1946] KB 219, the defendant (Naylor) was a farmer who had sold a portion of his farm to the plaintiff (Adams).
• The farm contained a private road which was used for access to both the sold and retained portions of the farm and a railway siding.
• The plaintiff sought a declaration that he had a right of way over this private road to access his property.

Issues
• The plaintiff argued that the easement of a right of way was implied by necessity when the farm was split and the land was sold.
• The defendant claimed that no such easement had been expressly reserved and that a right of way could not be inferred by necessity.

Decision
• The court held that an easement of right of way was implied by necessity, based on the nature of the property transactions and need for accessing the farm.
• The court rejected the defendant's argument and ruled in favour of the plaintiff, granting a declaration that Adams had a right of way over the road to access his portion of the farm.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is well-established law that an easement of way may be implied by necessity': (Denning J).
• 'No other way could be created or procured to get at the land except by going over this road. In those circumstances, I have reached the conclusion that a way of necessity must be implied over this road from the sold land to the retained land[...]': (Denning J).

cases.name: Street v Mountford [1985] AC 809
cases.summary:
Facts
• Street v Mountford [1985] AC 809 is a leading English property law case that clarified the distinction between a lease (tenancy) and a license.
• The case involved a dispute between a landlord (Street) and a tenant (Mountford) over the legal status of their agreement.
• Mrs. Mountford entered into an agreement with Mr. Street to occupy two rooms in his house under an 'exclusive possession' agreement for a weekly sum.
• The agreement was termed a 'licence' by the parties and included a clause stating it was not intended to create a tenancy.

Issues
• The issue before the court was whether the agreement constituted a tenancy or a license.
• Mr. Street argued that the agreement was a license because the parties had expressly agreed it was a license.
• Mrs. Mountford contended that the agreement actually constituted a tenancy, despite the label, due to the elements of exclusive possession and a periodic payment.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the agreement was a tenancy rather than a license.
• The court found that the parties' intentions could not override the objective reality of the legal relationship.
• The test for a tenancy is exclusive possession for a term at a rent, which the agreement met in substance despite the labels attached by the parties.
• The House of Lords emphasized that the distinction between a license and a tenancy is of great practical importance in the context of statutory protection for tenants.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is trite law that an agreement for the exclusive possession of residential accommodation for a term at a rent gives rise to a tenancy, unless there is some sufficient countervailing factor in the agreement or the surrounding circumstances to negative any intention on the part of the landlord to grant a tenancy to the occupier...' (Lord Templeman)

cases.name: Antoniades v Villiers [1990] 1 AC 417
cases.summary:
Facts
• Antoniades and Villiers were two unmarried individuals who entered into an agreement to rent a flat in London in 1985.
• The agreement contained a clause stating that the tenants could only occupy the property as a single private dwelling unit and not as a 'house in multiple occupation' (HMO).
• The agreement also contained a clause that prohibited the tenants from living together as man and wife.
• Antoniades and Villiers lived together as if they were married and in 1987, Antoniades succeeded in obtaining a declaration from the court that the prohibition against living together was a sham and therefore void.
• Villiers then sought to argue that the agreement as a whole was a sham, rendering the entire contract void.

Issues
• Was the agreement a sham rendering the entire contract void?
• Antoniades argued that only the clause prohibiting cohabitation was a sham, leaving the rest of the agreement valid.
• Villiers argued that the agreement as a whole was a sham, rendering the entire contract void.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that only the clause prohibiting cohabitation was a sham and void, leaving the rest of the agreement valid.
• The court reasoned that the clause prohibiting cohabitation was a sham because it was blatantly irrelevant to the purpose of the agreement and had no legitimate purpose.
• However, the rest of the agreement was not a sham because it governed the rights and duties of the landlord and tenant and had legitimate purposes.

Key passage(s)
• '[A] contract cannot be called a sham, simply because the parties to it agreed or contemplated that a clause, though not binding, would or might be invoked against third parties, and allowed the contract to go forward on that basis.' (Lord Bridge)

cases.name: Royal British Bank v Turquand (1856) 6 E. & B. 327
cases.summary:
Facts
• The Royal British Bank (the bank) loaned £2,000 to the directors of the insolvent Turquand’s company.
• The loan was made on a bond signed by the directors under the company's common seal.
• The constitution of the company required the consent of the general meetings for such a loan.
• The bank was not aware of these internal requirements, and it was not properly established if such consent had been provided.

Issues
• The bank argued it had a valid legal claim to the money loaned to Turquand’s company.
• Turquand’s legal representatives argued that the bond was not binding on the company because the necessary internal consent had not been procured.
• The court had to determine the validity of the bank’s claim against Turquand’s company based on the provided evidence.

Decision
• The court held that the bank could enforce the bond as an external party.
• The rule in Royal British Bank v Turquand, also known as the 'indoor management rule', was established.
• This rule states that external parties are entitled to presume that internal procedures have been properly followed, unless they have actual knowledge of the contrary.
• Turquand’s company was ordered to repay the £2,000 loaned amount to the bank.

Key passage(s)
• 'When there are persons conducting the affairs of the company in a manner which appears to be perfectly consonant with the articles of association, those so dealing with them externally are not to be affected by irregularities which may take place in the internal management of the company.' — Lord Campbell CJ

cases.name: AG v Jonathan Cape Ltd [1976] QB 752
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 1972, a former Cabinet minister, Mr Richard Crossman, died.
• He left behind diaries which contained accounts of government meetings and conversations with the Prime Minister and other senior ministers.
• The diaries were given to The Sunday Times for publication by Mr Crossman's literary executor.
• The Attorney General sought an injunction to prevent their publication, claiming that they were in breach of the Ministerial Code (the code of conduct for ministers) and the Official Secrets Act 1911 (OSA).

Issues
• The Attorney General argued that the publication of the diaries would amount to a breach of confidence, as they contained confidential and sensitive information.
• Jonathan Cape Ltd, the publisher, argued that the information was no longer confidential as Mr Crossman was dead, and that the public interest in having a full picture of government justified publication.

Decision
• The Court held that there was no breach of confidence.
• The Court found that there is no duty of confidentiality after the death of the person concerned.
• The Court also held that even if the diaries were still confidential, the public interest in their publication would outweigh any claim of confidentiality.
• The Court dismissed the Attorney General's claim that the diaries breached the Ministerial Code and the OSA, stating that these were intended to control ministers rather than regulate the publication of information.

Key passage(s)
• 'The judge held that the principle relating to confidence in equity is that proceedings will lie for breach of a duty of confidence placed upon a party by reason either of an agreement, expressed or implied, or of a relationship of confidence whenever such breach is likely to cause detriment to the party entitled to the confidence and provided such detriment is not so trivial as to justify the court in refusing to intervene.' (Lord Denning MR)

cases.name: DPP v Jones [1999] UKHL 5
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 1994, several individuals gathered on the highway near Stonehenge to hold a public protest against the construction of a road.
• The police arrested five individuals for obstructing the highway, including Michael Jones and Richard Lloyd-Roberts.
• They were charged under s137 of the Highways Act 1980 (HA 1980), which criminalises intentionally causing an unlawful and unreasonable obstruction of the highway.
• Jones and Lloyd-Roberts argued that the obstruction was not unreasonable since people have a general right to use the highway for peaceful assemblies and public protests.

Issues
• The case reached the House of Lords (now the Supreme Court) to determine whether people could rely on their common law right to assemble on a highway as a defence to a charge under s137 of the HA 1980.
• The prosecution argued that the common law right to assemble does not encompass use of a highway for anything other than passage.
• The defence argued that there is a common law right to use the highway for peaceful assemblies and public protests, which should override any restriction under s137 of the HA 1980.

Decision
• In a majority decision, the House of Lords held that the common law right to assemble on a highway did indeed exist, but that it was subject to limitations.
• The court found that the right to use the highway to assemble was not restricted to passage only as long as the assembly did not unreasonably obstruct the primary purpose of the highway, namely passage and repassage.
• As a result, Jones and Lloyd-Roberts were acquitted of the charges against them.

Key passage(s)
• 'At common law, the primary rights in relation to the highway are those of the public. They are rights of passage, not the private rights of the owner of the soil. But, subject to exceptions, they extend to the exercise by the public, at least temporarily, of what has been described as 'user of a reasonable and usual' kind.' - Lord Irvine of Lairg.
• 'In exercising their rights of passage along highways, people do so for various reasons and for various purposes. Protests and demonstrations, which are an integral part of the democratic society, are examples.' - Lord Hoffmann.

cases.name: R v Dimmock [1999] Crim LR 512
cases.summary:
Facts
• The defendant, Dimmock, entered a house using a key he had previously obtained and stole a video recorder.
• He had previously told his friends that he was going to take the video recorder and watch a film on it in his bedroom.
• Dimmock was subsequently charged with burglary under the Theft Act 1968, s 9(1)(b) (TA 1968).
• At trial, Dimmock claimed that he had no intention to deceive the house-owner permanently and would have returned the video recorder after watching the film.
• The trial judge directed the jury that Dimmock's intention to return the video recorder was irrelevant and he was convicted of burglary.

Issues
• The main issue on appeal was whether the trial judge erred in directing that Dimmock's intention to return the stolen property was irrelevant to the offence of burglary.
• The prosecution argued that even if he intended to return the stolen property, an intention to permanently deprive the owner of the property was not necessary for burglary under TA 1968, s 9(1)(b).
• The defence argued that the intention to return the property was relevant and should have been considered by the jury.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal allowed the appeal and quashed the conviction.
• The court held that the correct legal test for burglary is an intention to permanently deprive the owner of their property under TA 1968, s 9(1)(b).
• The court found that the trial judge's direction to the jury was wrong and that the intention to return the property was a relevant consideration.
• The court held that the proper course for the judge should have been to address the issue of intention to permanently deprive and not simply dismiss it as irrelevant.

Key passage(s)
• 'The rule laid down by the majority of the House of Lords in Easom [1971] AC 727 is that the definition of theft, including the mental element of dishonesty, applies to the offence of burglary under section 9(1)(b) of the Theft Act 1968.' (Lord Justice Schiemann)

cases.name: Addis v Gramophone Co Ltd [1909] AC 488
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Addis v Gramophone Co Ltd [1909] AC 488, the plaintiff, Mr. Addis, was wrongfully dismissed from his employment with the defendant, Gramophone Company.
• Addis was notified of his dismissal and given six months' salary in lieu of the notice period required under his employment contract.
• At the time of his dismissal, Addis was also informed that he would not be allowed to work the notice period and his successor would take over his duties immediately.
• Addis claimed damages for breach of contract and loss of reputation.

Issues
• The main issue in the case was whether Addis was entitled to damages for the loss of reputation caused by the manner in which he was dismissed.
• Addis argued that his dismissal was in breach of contract and he was entitled to damages for the losses suffered as a result.
• Gramophone Company contended that Addis was only entitled to damages for the wrongful dismissal itself, not for the additional loss of reputation.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that Addis was not entitled to damages for the loss of reputation caused by the manner of his dismissal.
• The Court reasoned that the manner of dismissal was not a term of the employment contract, and therefore, Addis could not claim a breach of contract for the manner by which he was dismissed.
• Additionally, the Court held that damages for loss of reputation caused by the manner of dismissal were too remote and not recoverable.

Key passage(s)
• 'There is no doubt that if a man gets a bad reputation from being dismissed from his situation he may find it more difficult than otherwise to get a new one; but I cannot see how that is a subject of damages under an action for wrongful dismissal' (Lord Loreburn).
• 'The real complaint of the plaintiff is not the manner of dismissal, but its innuendo... [The innuendo] does not give rise to a fresh cause of action' (Lord Atkinson).
• 'The damage to the plaintiff's feelings in the manner of the wrongful dismissal is too remote, for purposes of a claim of this description, to be considered' (Lord James of Hereford).

cases.name: R v Pembliton (1874) LR 2 CCR 119
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R v Pembliton (1874) LR 2 CCR 119, the defendant was involved in a fight at a pub.
• He threw a large stone at the group he was fighting with, but the stone missed and broke a nearby window.
• Pembliton was charged with maliciously and unlawfully damaging property.

Issues
• The issue in this case was whether the defendant's actions constituted the offence of maliciously and unlawfully damaging property.
• The prosecution argued that Pembliton's actions were unlawful because he intended to harm the group he was fighting with and accidentally damaged the window.
• The defence argued that as Pembliton did not intend to damage the window, his actions were not malicious.

Decision
• The court held that Pembliton's actions did not constitute the offence of maliciously and unlawfully damaging property.
• The court reasoned that since Pembliton did not intend to damage the window, his actions were not malicious.
• The conviction was quashed on appeal.

Key passage(s)
• 'Where a party does an act with intent to injure another, but in so doing accidentally commits another injury of a totally different and distinct kind from that intended he is not, in law, guilty of having committed the latter injury either crimes or civiliter.' (Cleasby B)
• 'It seems to me that, in this case, the jury have found that the prisoner intended only one mischief - that of striking the persons from whom the stone rebounded; and, if that be so, the question resolves itself into this, - whether that finding is sufficient to make the injury resulting from the stone breaking the window, a malicious injury within the section.' (Lord Coleridge)

cases.name: Young v Bristol Aeroplane Co Ltd [1944] KB 718
cases.summary:
Facts
• Young v Bristol Aeroplane Co Ltd [1944] KB 718 is a landmark decision that established the principles of inconsistency in the Court of Appeal (England and Wales).
• The case concerned two striking machinists employed by the Bristol Aeroplane Company.
• They were dismissed due to the breakdown in relations between them and their employer as a result of their strike activities.
• They brought a claim for unfair dismissal and argued that their dismissal was in breach of their contracts of employment.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the Court of Appeal had the power to depart from its own previous decisions.
• The claimants argued that there was a binding authority that supported their case, namely Burton and Another v London and North Western Railway Co (1912) TLR 133, which held that employees cannot be dismissed for striking.
• The defendants argued that the Court of Appeal should overturn Burton as it was no longer good law.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal, led by Lord Greene MR, decided that the court does have the power to depart from its own previous decisions when it is in the interests of justice to do so.
• The court also set out three exceptions to the general rule of stare decisis (the doctrine stating that courts should abide by their own prior decisions), which are:
1) if a previous decision is inconsistent with a higher court's decision;
2) if there are two previous inconsistent decisions;
3) if a previous decision is based on a mistaken assumption that has since been overturned.
• In this case, the court found that there were previous inconsistent decisions, and therefore the court could depart from the precedent set in Burton.
• Consequently, the court ruled in favour of the defendants holding that the dismissal of the claimants was justified.

Key passage(s)
• 'In the interest of the proper administration of justice, and more especially in the interest of certainty, courts exercising inferior jurisdiction are bound to follow decisions of courts exercising superior jurisdiction which are binding on their own jurisdiction' (Lord Greene MR).
• 'The only case in which the Court of Appeal has power to depart from a previous determination of its own is when it is satisfied that the earlier decision was given per incuriam, that is to say … without the advantage of full argument …' (Denning LJ).

cases.name: R v Kennedy [2007] UKHL 38
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant, Kennedy, supplied heroin to the deceased.
• The deceased injected himself with the heroin, resulting in an overdose and subsequent death.
• Kennedy was charged and convicted with manslaughter and supplying a controlled drug.
• The conviction was based on principles derived from cases such as R v Dalby (1982) and R v Dias (2001).

Issues
• The appellant argued that his actions did not cause the death, as the deceased's voluntary action of injecting himself broke the chain of causation.
• The prosecution argued that Kennedy's act of supplying the drug was a substantial and operating cause of the death, and therefore constituted manslaughter.

Decision
• The House of Lords quashed Kennedy's manslaughter conviction.
• They held that the deceased's voluntary and informed decision to inject himself broke the chain of causation.
• Kennedy could not be held liable for the deceased's death, as there was a novus actus interveniens (a new intervening act).
• The cases of Dalby and Dias were distinguished, as they did not concern an intervening voluntary act.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is neither reasonable nor just to hold a supplier of a drug who may, for all the court knows, have warned the person to whom he supplied it of the dangers of taking an overdose, guilty of manslaughter when, with full knowledge of those dangers, that person freely and voluntarily decides to inject the drug into his bloodstream.' (Lord Bingham)
• 'The voluntary, informed and deliberate decision of one party may reduce the causal potency of the earlier act which would otherwise have been a cause of the outcome.' (Lord Hoffman)

cases.name: M'Naghten Case (1843) 10 Cl. & Fin. 200
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 1843, Daniel M'Naghten, suffering from paranoid delusions, attempted to assassinate British Prime Minister Sir Robert Peel but accidentally killed Peel's secretary, Edward Drummond.
• M'Naghten was charged with murder, to which he pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity.

Issues
• At trial, the defense presented medical evidence demonstrating M'Naghten's delusional state, arguing that he should not be held criminally responsible due to his insanity.
• The prosecution, on the other hand, argued that since M'Naghten understood the nature of his act and knew it was wrong, he should be held accountable.

Decision
• The jury found M'Naghten not guilty by reason of insanity, following which the House of Lords asked the judges to set out legal principles for determining insanity in future cases.
• The judges established the M'Naghten Rules as the benchmark test for criminal liability in cases of insanity, which require a defendant to either not know the nature and quality of their act or not know that it was wrong at the time.

Key passage(s)
• 'To establish a defense on the ground of insanity, it must be clearly proved that, at the time of the committing of the act, the party accused was labouring under such a defect of reason, from disease of the mind, as not to know the nature and quality of the act he was doing; or, if he did know it, that he did not know he was doing what was wrong.' (Lord Chief Justice Tindal)
• 'The question to be determined is, whether at the time the act in question was committed, the prisoner had or had not the use of his understanding, so as to know that he was doing a wrong or wicked act.' (Lord Chief Baron Pollock)

cases.name: AG v McWhirter [1977] VR 428
cases.summary:
Facts
• In AG v McWhirter [1977] VR 428, the defendant, Alexander McWhirter, placed an advertisement in the personal column of a newspaper.
• The advertisement read: 'Wanted. Experienced abortionist. Well-paid position available.'
• The newspaper refused to publish the advertisement.
• The Attorney General filed an ex officio indictment against McWhirter, alleging that he had solicited the commission of a crime.

Issues
• The issue was whether the advertisement constituted an attempt to solicit a crime.
• The Attorney General argued that it did, and therefore McWhirter should be held criminally liable for his actions.
• McWhirter argued that the advertisement did not meet the necessary elements to be considered a solicitation of a crime.

Decision
• The Victorian Supreme Court found McWhirter guilty of attempting to solicit a crime by advertising for an abortionist.
• The court reasoned that, although McWhirter had not successfully found an abortionist through the advertisement, his conduct was an attempt to engage in conduct that would lead to the commission of a crime.
• It was held that an attempt to solicit a crime does not require that the person solicited actually commits or agrees to commit the crime.
• The court followed the approach adopted in R v Higgins (1801) 2 East 5 PC, where it was held that an attempt to commit a crime was itself a crime.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is not necessary that the person to whom the solicitation is addressed should agree to do what is asked nor make any further step toward the commission of the substantive offence.' (Adam J)

cases.name: Re A (Conjoined Twins) [2000] 4 All ER 961
cases.summary:
Facts
